column7: By the shore in the warmer areas of C. Japan[58].
column16: Rubus trifidus is an evergreen Shrub growing to 2 m (6ft 7in).  See above for USDA hardiness. It is hardy to UK zone 6. It is in leaf all year, in flower in May. The species is hermaphrodite (has both male and female organs) and is pollinated by Insects.  Suitable for: light (sandy), medium (loamy) and heavy (clay) soils and prefers  well-drained soil. Suitable pH: mildly acid, neutral and basic (mildly alkaline) soils. It can grow in  semi-shade (light woodland) or no shade. It prefers  moist soil. The plant can tolerate maritime exposure.
column21: Fruit - raw or cooked[1, 11, 58, 105]. A grateful taste[2].
column23: Plants For A Future can not take any responsibility for any adverse effects from the use of plants. Always seek advice from a professional before using a plant medicinally.None known
column25: A purple to dull blue dye is obtained from the fruit[168].
column27: Easily grown in a good well-drained loamy soil in sun or semi-shade[1, 11, 200]. Plants are evergreen when grown in a sheltered woodland[182]. Often cultivated for its edible fruit in Japan[58], plants do not flower very freely in Britain[11]. Plants have perennial stems that are thornless[200]. Plants in this genus are notably susceptible to honey fungus[200].
column28: Seed - requires stratification and is best sown in early autumn in a cold frame. Stored seed requires one month stratification at about 3°c and is best sown as early as possible in the year. Prick out the seedlings when they are large enough to handle and grow on in a cold frame. Plant them out into their permanent positions in late spring of the following year. Cuttings of half-ripe wood, July/August in a frame[200]. Tip layering in July. Plant out in autumn. Division in early spring or just before leaf-fall in the autumn[200].
